headline.main: Obama Visits Swing States Before Convention

docs.abstract: With his party's nominating convention approaching, President Obama started a four-day campaign swing in Iowa on Saturday, returning to the state where he opened his unlikely quest for the presidency five years ago.
docs.snippet: With his party's nominating convention approaching, President Obama started a four-day campaign swing in Iowa on Saturday, returning to the state where he opened his unlikely quest for the presidency five years ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans, even House challengers, are distancing themselves from the proposed Medicare cuts in Paul D. Ryan’s budget plan, even as he and Mitt Romney urge them to embrace it.

headline.seo: Republican Troops Keeping Ryan’s Budget Plan at Arm’s Length
headline.main: Ryan’s Budget Proposal Is Pitting G.O.P. Troops Against Top of the Ticket
headline.print_headline: Ryan’s Budget Proposal Is Pitting G.O.P. Troops Against Top of the Ticket

docs.abstract: Republican lawmakers and candidates are distancing themselves from Rep Paul D Ryan's budget plan, which helped make proposed Medicare changes and spending cuts a national issue.
docs.snippet: Republicans, even House challengers, are distancing themselves from the proposed Medicare cuts in Paul D. Ryan’s budget plan, even as he and Mitt Romney urge them to embrace it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Few other issues present a starker difference between the two tickets, with President Obama seeking a big expansion and the Republicans pushing big cuts.

headline.seo: Campaigns Have Sharply Different Visions for Medicaid
headline.main: 2 Campaigns Differ Sharply on Medicaid, Seeking Vast Growth or Vast Cuts
headline.print_headline: 2 Campaigns Differ Sharply on Medicaid, Seeking Vast Growth or Vast Cuts

docs.abstract: Outcome of the 2012 election will probably have a more immediate and profound effect on Medicaid, despite both campaigns' insistence on framing the election as a debate about the future of Medicare.
docs.snippet: Few other issues present a starker difference between the two tickets, with President Obama seeking a big expansion and the Republicans pushing big cuts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent events in the contest between President Obama and Mitt Romney have raised new questions about whether the political culture still holds any penalty for falsehood.

headline.seo: Fact-Checkers Howl, but Both Sides Cling to False Ads
headline.main: Campaigns Play Loose With Truth in a Fact-Check Age
headline.print_headline: Fact-Checkers Howl, but Campaigns Seem Attached to Dishonest Ads

docs.abstract: Political Memo; recent events in the contest between Pres Obama and Mitt Romney have raised new questions about the role of dishonesty in political campaigns and whether the political culture still holds any penalty for campaigns that peddle falsehoods.
docs.snippet: Recent events in the contest between President Obama and Mitt Romney have raised new questions about whether the political culture still holds any penalty for falsehood.

docs.lead_paragraph: Good news, people! There was plenty of time on the flight home from Tampa to read through the Republican Party’s platform for you.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column mocks several hypocritical and vague elements of the Republican Party's official platform; argues that it fails to address real problems facing the poor and middle classes, while repeating tired platitudes about the merits of the free market.
docs.snippet: Good news, people! There was plenty of time on the flight home from Tampa to read through the Republican Party’s platform for you.

docs.lead_paragraph: To discharge student loans in bankruptcy, a borrower may have to convince a judge that life will never get better and destitution is certain.

headline.seo: Last Chance to Shed School Loans: Proving All Is Hopeless
headline.main: Last Plea on School Loans: Proving a Hopeless Future
headline.print_headline: Last Plea on School Loans: Proving a Hopeless Future

docs.abstract: Majority of those who declare bankruptcy do not even attempt to have their student loans erased, facing stiff federal laws that require them to convince a federal judge that there is a 'certainty of hopelessness' to their financial lives for much of the repayment period; Congress, in an effort to protect taxpayer money, has toughened laws related to forgiving student loans several times since the 1970s, even extending them to private loans in 2005 (Series: Degrees of Debt).
docs.snippet: To discharge student loans in bankruptcy, a borrower may have to convince a judge that life will never get better and destitution is certain.
